prompt: Facts: Sanjeev Singh (Appellant) married Amandeep Kaur (deceased) on October 18, 2009.; Amandeep Kaur died on July 12, 2010 (within 9 months of marriage) in her matrimonial home.; FIR No. 83 dated July 12, 2010, was registered at Police Station City Ahmedgarh, District Sangrur, Punjab, based on the statement of Mukhtiar Singh (PW-1, father of the deceased).; Allegations involved demands for dowry (specifically a car) and consequent harassment and cruelty towards the deceased by the appellant.; PW-1 stated that dowry demands started soon after marriage and continued, leading to the deceased being upset and informing her parents.; A panchayat meeting was allegedly held about 15 days before the death to resolve the issue, where the appellant reiterated the demand for a car.; Post-mortem examination conducted by Dr. Gurmanjit Rai (PW-4) concluded the cause of death was 'asphyxia due to strangulation which is sufficient to cause death in ordinary course of nature'. Ligature mark details were noted.; The defense pleaded that the deceased committed suicide by hanging.; The Trial Court convicted the appellant under Sections 304B and 498A of the IPC on October 29, 2011.; Sentence awarded: Rigorous Imprisonment (RI) for 10 years under Section 304B IPC and RI for 3 years with a fine of Rs. 5,000/- under Section 498A IPC. Sentences to run concurrently.; The High Court of Punjab and Haryana dismissed the appellant's appeal and upheld the Trial Court's judgment on May 25, 2020.; The appellant (Sanjeev Singh) filed the present appeal before the Supreme Court challenging the High Court's decision.; Key prosecution witnesses included Mukhtiar Singh (PW-1, father), Surjit Kaur (PW-2, mother), Dr. Gurmanjit Rai (PW-4, conducted post-mortem), and ASI Baldev Singh (PW-6, Investigating Officer).; Key defense witnesses included Gurmeet Singh (DW-1) and Kuldeep Singh @ Keepa (DW-2), neighbors who testified about the appellant's character and lack of knowledge about dowry demands. | IPC: Section 304B (Dowry Death), Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty), Section 302 (Murder - discussed contextually), Section 306 (Abetment of suicide - relevant due to defense plea)
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "The essential ingredients of Section 304B IPC are fully satisfied: death occurred within 7 years of marriage (9 months), under unnatural circumstances (strangulation), and evidence proves dowry-related cruelty 'soon before' death.", "precedents": ["Kans Raj v. State of Punjab (2000) 5 SCC 207 (Defines ingredients of 304B)", "Rajbir @ Raju v. State of Haryana (2010) 15 SCC 116 (Presumption under S.113B Evidence Act is mandatory once foundational facts proven)", "Gurdeep Singh v. State of Punjab & Ors. (2022) SCC OnLine SC 153 (Reiterates principles for 304B conviction)"]}, {"argument": "The testimonies of the deceased's parents (PW-1 and PW-2) are consistent, credible, and establish a continuous pattern of dowry demands (car) and harassment, constituting cruelty under Section 498A IPC.", "precedents": ["Girdhar Shankar Tawade v. State of Maharashtra (2002) 5 SCC 177 (Defines 'cruelty' under 498A)", "State of Karnataka v. H.S. Srinivasa (2007) 12 SCC 550 (Parental testimony reliable in dowry cases)", "Surinder Kumar v. State of Haryana (2011) 10 SCC 173 (Consistency in witness accounts)"]}, {"argument": "Medical evidence (post-mortem report by PW-4) definitively proves death by homicidal strangulation, directly contradicting the defense's unsubstantiated claim of suicide by hanging.", "precedents": ["State of Punjab v. Iqbal Singh (1991) 3 SCC 1 (Importance of medical evidence in establishing cause of death)", "Balwant Singh v. State of Punjab (2004) 7 SCC 724 (Distinguishing strangulation vs. hanging based on ligature marks)", "Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra (1984) 4 SCC 116 (Medical evidence as crucial circumstantial evidence)"]}], "defense": [{"argument": "The prosecution failed to establish a clear 'proximate and live link' between the alleged dowry demands/harassment and the time of death. The 'soon before death' element required for Section 304B is not proven beyond reasonable doubt.", "precedents": ["Major Singh v. State of Punjab (2015) 5 SCC 201 (Emphasis on proximity)", "Surinder Singh v. State of Haryana (2014) 4 SCC 129 (Live link required)", "Baijnath & Ors v. State of Madhya Pradesh (2017) 1 SCC 101 (Meaning of 'soon before death')"]}, {"argument": "The primary evidence comes from the deceased's parents (PW-1, PW-2), who are interested witnesses. Their testimony suffers from inconsistencies and lacks independent corroboration, making it unreliable for conviction.", "precedents": ["Kans Raj v. State of Punjab (2000) 5 SCC 207 (Scrutiny of interested witnesses)", "State of Haryana v. Ram Singh (2002) 2 SCC 426 (Need for corroboration when witnesses are relatives)", "Bhajan Singh @ Harbhajan Singh & Ors v. State of Haryana (2011) 7 SCC 421 (Credibility assessment of witnesses)"]}, {"argument": "The possibility of suicide by hanging has not been conclusively ruled out by the prosecution. The burden of proof lies entirely on the prosecution to establish homicide beyond all reasonable doubt.", "precedents": ["Kali Ram v. State of Himachal Pradesh (1973) 2 SCC 808 (Prosecution must prove its case irrespective of defense weakness)", "State of West Bengal v. Orilal Jaiswal (1994) 1 SCC 73 (Distinction between abetment of suicide and dowry death scenarios)", "Satbir Singh v. State of Haryana (2021) 6 SCC 1 (Discusses interplay of presumptions and burden of proof)"]}]}
